text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name NORMAN F SCOTT
Present Address 710, EASTLAKE AVE., SASKATOON
Pioneer Address SASKATOON-ASQUITH-JUNIATA
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1904
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaires.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? **10**
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? **3**

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? **WEEKLY IN SUMMER**

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? **SUNDAYS**

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? **YES - A LOT OF VISITING DONE WITHOUT INVITATION**
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? **AFTERNOON**
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? **YES**
   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) **TAKEN AS GRANTED THAT VISITORS WOULD STAY FOR MEALS IF MEALTIME**
   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? **DRINKS & SANDWICHES**

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? **DEPENDING ON NUMBERS OF LIVESTOCK**

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? **YES**
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. **A BEE TO ERRECT A SCHOOL BARN - 1921**

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. **YES - IN YEARS 1908 TO 1909 DANCES - YOUNG PEOPLE WOULD DRIVE UP TO 20 MILES**

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. **NO**

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? **NO**
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 5
Florser Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first ten years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 10

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? WEEKLY IN SUMMER

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? SUNDAYS

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? YES - A LOT OR VISITING DONE WITHOUT INVITATION

What time of the day did you go - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? AFTERNOON

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? YES

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "make yourself at home" used, or was some other expression common?) TAKEN AS GRANTED THAT VISITORS WOULD STAY FOR MEALS IF MEALTIME

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? DRINKS & SANDWICHES

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "neese" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? YES

Tell what you remember about such gatherings giving dates if possible, telling that the "neese" was for and how often they occurred.

A BEE TO ERRECT A SCHOOL BARN - 1921

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, visits, drives or dances in homes? Describe. YES - IN YEARS 1905 TO 1907

DANCES - YOUNG PEOPLE WOULD DRIVE UP TO 20 MILES

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. NO

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? NO
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

SCHOOL WAS USED FOR CHRISTMAS ENTERTAINMENTS & SCHOOL PICNICS

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe. SCHOOL WAS SOCIAL CENTRE

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? — How large was it? —

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? —

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? —

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? YES

How were babies and small children provided for? PARENT'S CARED FOR THEM

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? BARN & SHEDS

11. What card games were popular in the early days? WHIST

Was there card playing for a prize? SOMETIMES

What dances were popular? ALL

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. NO

NO DANCING ALLOWED IN FAIRHOLME SCHOOL

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. GENERALLY ACCEPTED

ONE OR TWO FAMILIES OBJECTED UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnic, etc.)

If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

SCHOOL WAS USED FOR CHRISTMAS ENTERTAINMENTS

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe. SCHOOL WAS SOCIAL CENTRE

9. When was your first community hall built?

That material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? YES

How were babies and small children provided for? PARENT'S CARED

FOR THEM

BARN'S SHEDS

11. What card games were popular in the early days? WHIST

Has there been playing for prizes? SOMETIMES

What dances were popular? ALL

Was there ever any disapproval between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. NO

NO DANCING ALLOWED IN FAIRHOLME SCHOOL

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home or for community gatherings? Explain. GENERALLY ACCEPTED

ONE OR TWO FAMILIES OBJECTED UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? **CALLING CARDS WERE IN VOGUE FOR A SHORT TIME**

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? **NO**
   Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. **ONLY REMEMBER THEM IN ONTARIO**

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

**ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.**

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? **SASKATCHEWAN GRAIN GROWERS ASSOCIATION**
   Give the date and reason for it being organized. **1908 - THE BELIEF IT WOULD HELP REMOVE CERTAIN INJUSTICES**

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? **YES**
   Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. **AS ABOVE**

   Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? **ONE HALF**
   How many women belonged? **1/2**
   How often did it meet? **MONTHLY**

   What were some of the activities carried on by this organisation? **GENERALLY HAVING SPEAKERS FROM EXTENSION DEPT. U.O.F.S. AND OTHER PROMINENT PEOPLE - FOR A TIME BUYING SUPPLIES FOR MEMBERS.**

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? **NO**
   When was it organized?
   Approximately how many women belonged to it?
   Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3. What attempts at formality, or "haunting," do you remember in small towns, such as glove and hat when calling, calling cards, visiting in parlor, etc.? CALLING CARDS WERE IN VOGUE FOR A SHORT TIME

12. Was the chivaree known in your community? No
Describe what you remember about chivarees; telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc., ONLY REMEMBER THEM

14. Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc., that you remember; telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned, that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can; when social life became noticeable.

IN ONTARIO

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can recall, before becoming established in your community? SASKATCHEWAN GRAIN GROWERS ASSOCIATION
Give the date and reason for its being organized. 1908 — THE BELIEF IT WOULD HELP REMOVE CERTAIN INJUSTICES

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. AS ABOVE

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?
ONE HALF

How many women belonged? 1/2
How often did it meet? MONTHLY

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? GENERALLY HAVING SPEAKERS FROM EXTENSION DEPT. U. OF S. AND OTHER PROMINENT PEOPLE FOR A TIME BUYING SUPPLIES FOR MEMBERS

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No
When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? **CANVAS**

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? **SCHOOL HOUSES**

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? **NO**

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? —— Give dates if possible. ——
Who provided the lantern and the slides? ——
What were the slides about? ——

**CHILDREN'S GAMES**

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? **BALL - MARBLES**

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? **AS MENTIONED**
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, and purpose. (Name only those organizations which were connected with the church, as they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? 

Canvas

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? School Houses

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Yes

Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-numbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball - Marbles

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? As mentioned
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? **SKATING**

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? **AUTHORS - CHECKERS**

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain. **VERY LITTLE - MOSTLY CHILDREN**

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. **TOO BUSY**

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe. **NOT MUCH**

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. **CAN'T REMEMBER**

26. Who organized it? **—**

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? **—**

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? **—**

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? **—**

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? **—**

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? **—**

31. What did you have to eat and drink? **—**

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? **—**
5. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? SKATING

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? AUTHORS - CHECKERS

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

VERY LITTLE - MOSTLY CHILDREN

23. Was there much time for games or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? EXPLAIN. TOO BUSY

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe. NOT MUCH

PIONEER AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. CAN'T REMEMBER

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

   What year? ______ How long did it continue? ______

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? ______
6. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember or still stand out.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as school picnics, school or Sunday school picnics, family picnics, etc., tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (e.g., women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? — Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? — Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? — When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

PRACTICALLY NONE

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? 3 OR 4

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? NONE

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. YES VARIOUS

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? NONE

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. YES — PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT 1924 TO 1938

48. Was there a school library? YES When was it begun? 1921

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? VERY LITTLE

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
40. Then did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? —
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plan? —
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? —
   What was the sports day usually held (what month, or any special day, such
   as May 24th or July 4th)? —
   Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
   hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names, and dates. —

41. Practically None

REMARKS:

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
   books and authors, if possible.) If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
   books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? 3 or 4
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? NONE

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details. YES

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? NONE

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
   Give dates and dates. YES — PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT
   1824 to 1938

48. Was there a school library? YES
   When was it begun? 1821

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
   material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? **YES**
   When was it started? **1924** Who started it? **TEACHER**
   Is it still in existence? **NO**
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why? **TOO FEW PEOPLE**

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

   **75 - SCHOOL - TEACHER - TIME RULE 2 WEEKS**

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? **FREE PRESS WEEKLY**
    **FAMILY HERALD & WEEKLY STAR**
    **WEEKLY SASKATOON PHOENIX**

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

   **NOW SASKATOON STAR PHOENIX DAILY**
   **ADDED - MACLEAN'S - COUNTRY GUIDE - WESTERN PRODUCER**
   **- SASK. FARMER - FARM & RANCH REVIEW**
   **STAR WEEKLY - READERS DIGEST**
   **PERDOUE RECORD**

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? **NO**
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

   **NONE**

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. **NO**
   **TOO MUCH WORK**
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? YES

When was it started? 1924

Was it still in existence? NO

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? TOO FEW PEOPLE

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

73. SCHOOL - TEACHER - TIME RULE 2 WEEKS

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

FREE PRESS WEEKLY
FAMILY HERALD & WEEKLY STAR
WEEKLY SASKATOON PHOENIX

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you changed or added others.

NOW SASKATOON STAR PHOENIX DAILY
ADDED - MACLEAN'S - COUNTRY GUIDE - WESTERN PRODUCER
- SASK. FARMER - FARM & RANCH REVIEW
- STAR WEEKLY - READERS DIGEST
PERDUE RECORD

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? NO

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

NONE

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. NO

TOO MUCH WORK
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? **NONE**

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? **A VERY FEW ORGANS + PIANOS - QUITE A NUMBER OF VIOLINS - GUITARS + ACCORDIONS**

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. **SECOND HAND ORGAN - 75 DOLLARS - BRANDON PIANO - 1000 DOLLARS - MINNEAPOLIS**

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. **SINGING POPULAR GRAMAPHONES & PHONEGRAPHS COMMON**

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. **VERY LITTLE**

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? **SWANEE RIVER JEANIE WITH THE LIGHT BROWN HAIR SILVER THREADS AMONG THE GOLD - SWEET AFTON OLD BLACK JOE - MOONLIGHT BAY - RED RIVER VALLEY**

in the community? **AS ABOVE**

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. **NO**

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. **NO**

63. Was there a band in your community? — When was it started? —
Who started it? — How long did it continue? —
How many were in it? — Who was bandmaster?
What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring when you moved? None

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? A VERY FEW

58. ORGANS - PIANOS - GUITARS - A NUMBER OF VIOLINS

59. How large a party did you sing at? Describe. SINGING POPULAR

60. What was some of the favorite songs in the home? SWANEE RIVER

61. Was FOLK music, or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. NO

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. NO

63. Was there a band in your community? WHEN WAS IT STARTED?

WHO STARTED IT?

HOW LONG DID IT CONTINUE?

HOW MANY WERE IN IT?

WHO WAS BANDMASTER?

WHAT INSTRUMENTS WERE INCLUDED?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances. **NO**

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? **LESS FEW PEOPLE**

**HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.**

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? **NO**

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. **NO**

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned. **NONE**

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? **NO**

**GENERAL**

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearance. **NO**

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? **LESS**

**FEW PEOPLE**

**HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS**

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? **NO**

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a close-up illustration of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. **NO**

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned. **NONE**

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? **NO**

**GENERAL**

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of pages, or extra sheets if necessary).
Oxford
No. 613 S
